awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Investigation of Archaeological Communities of Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this doctoral dissertation project is to understand the impact of colonialism on the daily activities of Native Americans and their response to the rapid changes that took place after European contact.  Because most historical documents about this region were written by men, the experience of Native American women has been neglected. This project addresses this disparity by focusing specifically on one of the products of the everyday activities of women and the importance and stability of the networks of learning that developed among women around the practice of pottery production. This project emphasizes the stability of these communities and the choices made by female potters to demonstrate that these women were agents of change and to counter dominant narratives that depict Native Americans as passive victims of an unstoppable colonial force. From a theoretical perspective, this work improves researchers’ understandings of how working groups of individuals - in this case traditional potters - are maintained in the face of significant political and social change. 

These issues will be addressed through the analysis of pottery from four cultural sites located in coastal Georgia and South Carolina. The doctoral student will utilize visual inspection of pottery decoration and attributes related to production. Similarities and differences in these traits will allow her to identify sites that were occupied by potters who likely learned to produce pottery together or spent significant amounts of time engaged in pottery production together. She will also utilize petrographic microscopy for a more detailed look at how production processes vary between sites. The pottery samples have been selected specifically to allow researchers to address how the networks connecting women at the study sites changed or were maintained through time. Radiocarbon dating will be used to ensure that any variation that is observed is the result of differences in potting communities, rather than change through time. This research will be presented to the nearest descendants of the tribe in question, the Muskogee (Creek) Nation. This offers members of the tribe an archaeological perspective on their history and facilitate positive relationships between academic archaeologists and descendant communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Elizabeth Straub, a PhD candidate at the University of Kentucky, analyzed  pottery produced by a Native American tribe called the Guale with the hope of learning about the impact of colonialism on the daily activities of Native Americans and their response to the rapid changes that took place after European contact in the 14th to 16th centuries. Due to the fact that most historical documents about this region were written by Spanish men, the experience of Native American women has been neglected. This project addresses this disparity by focusing specifically on one of the products of the everyday activities of women and the importance and stability of the networks of learning that developed among women around the practice of pottery production. This project emphasizes the stability of these communities and the choices made by female potters to demonstrate that these women were agents of change and to counter dominant narratives that depict Native Americans as passive victims of an unstoppable colonial force. 

Ms. Straub has analyzed and compared ceramics from multiple sites along the Georgia and South Carolina coasts, including Pueblo North on St. Catherines Island (9Li2117), the Sapelo Island Shell Rings (9Mc23), Darien Bluff on the mainland adjacent to Sapelo Island (9Mc10), and Altamaha Town in southern South Carolina (38Bu20/1206 and 38Bu1836/1837) (Figure 1). 

Prior to 1660, Guale potters on Sapelo Island, at Darien Bluff, and at Pueblo North were closely related. Relationships between potters at all of these sites, which were based on shared traditions and working together, continued after 1660 despite significant political and demographic change. This continuity is likely due to the fact that the community was so widespread, allowing it to absorb the loss of some community members without disrupting the passing down of cultural knowledge and also allowing displaced potters to settle with with people who shared their traditions, where they would be able to maintain their potting practices without sacrificing a sense of belonging in their new community.

Altamaha Town, a late 17th-century site occupied by a tribe called the Yamasee, along with Guale refugees, may not have belonged to the same community of potters. The distinctive nature of this assemblage, which does have some traits of coastal Guale pottery, may suggest that potters at Altamaha Town shared some of their potting history with potters from Sapelo Island, Darien Bluff, and Pueblo North. In this sense, they may be thought of as more distantly related to potters at the other sites considered here.

On the other hand, it is possible that some potters at Altamaha Town were part of the same community as potters from Sapelo Island, Darrien Bluff, and Pueblo North, while other potters belonged to a different community. This makes sense since there is significant variation between pottery from different parts of Altamaha Town, with some of that pottery being very similar to pottery from coastal Georgia. Additional research focused on variability in pottery from Altamaha Town is needed to find out which of these possibilities is most likely.

Increased diversity in pottery after 1660, as well as significant differences between pottery from different locations at Altamaha Town, may be the result of increasing diversity. As refugees settled at these coastal sites, they may have introduced diversity in some traits as they became incorporated into the local potting community. 

The data presented here indicate that there were strong ties between communities of women at these sites. Not only do these women share a history of learning, a tradition of pottery production, but they likely spent at least some time making pottery together. Relationships like these may have eased and even shaped responses to social and political change, both before and after the Mission Period.

The role that women and their social ties played in various political and cultural processes needs further consideration. The spread of a single pottery style across the entire eastern mission region was surely not the work of men or of Europeans. Most likely, it was the work of women building connections with one another. Understanding how communities of potters formed and how their relationships changed may be important for understanding how tribes throughout this region navigated political turmoil.
